Twitter is deeply imperfect, but I hope it survives as a place to connect with people of different perspectives and experiences that are just as vital and fundamentally American as any other. Take it from someone who needed to see them to change his own perspective for the better

It‚Äôs why Musk wants Twitter, and why everyone from your state Democratic Party to local editorial board to tiresome group of NIMBY ‚Äúliberals‚Äù views it with suspicion. 

And it‚Äôs why every bigot and weird GOP state legislator and insurrectionist wants to succeed at it. Or buy it.

Twitter‚Äôs just a website - but one that allowed marginalized voices in my own community to speak up, and forced people like me to listen and try to understand. I can only hope that continues, bc out here our newspapers, tv, radio - all of it - is built to maintain old hierarchies

Twitter suffered from the biases and cruelties of our larger culture. But it beat the hell out of the local paper that endorsed a white nationalist. And it led me to propose more just & empathetic policy in a place groaning under the weight of old ideas and blinkered perspectives

Twitter allowed someone like me - from small town homogenous Montana - to see other perspectives and understand different ways of fighting power structures. And it empowered marginalized groups in Montana to rise above our dying rural media.

It widened our view of the world.

I know of towns in eastern Montana currently building housing for their public servants. We have the confidence, and we have the money (which matters sadly!) to do it bigger and better. So just build the fucking housing. Bozeman isn‚Äôt everyone‚Äôs future. And nobody wants it to be.

(Our leaders know this - some of them mistakenly equate unequal growth with broad-based prosperity, some wanna cash in‚Ä¶the reasons don‚Äôt matter. Their failure to have any substantive answer to their communities‚Äô most pressing needs for housing *is* what matters. Anyways‚Ä¶)

But the last decade of watching this wave coming, watching it make Bozeman into Aspen, watching it change Missoula and the Flathead for the worse, has produced‚Ä¶nothing. Our leaders have no answers other than vague promises to reform zoning. It‚Äôs not gonna be enough.

Other towns, other regions - they are not guides, they are cautionary tales. We know this. Part of the privilege of living here - a place experiencing explosive growth - is having the opportunity to see how other American communities‚Äô policies have failed & to blaze our own trail

Western Montanans: If we really are a place apart, if our pride in our communities is more than just bullshit marketing for the tourists, then we must provide that most basic of thing - a place to live - for everyone in our community. 

Otherwise we‚Äôre just vacation towns.

Your town building and renting apts to underpaid teachers, firefighters, and janitors isn‚Äôt communism. They‚Äôre not gonna put a Soviet apartment block in downtown Missoula or wherever.

Local govts must aggressively build workforce housing for a more diverse and equitable future.

And zoning reform - even if you could reason with the ‚Äúneighborhood character‚Äù crowd - leaves the actual building of houses for a more diverse or less uniformly rich citizenry to developers. But they claim the margins aren‚Äôt high enough.

We gotta build it ourselves.

The demography and inequity of our communities has been fostered by the racist and classist policies of our local govts for decades.

But try for zoning reform and you‚Äôll get a chorus of self-described liberals braying about thahr propertay rahts (aka their overpriced bungalows).

Don‚Äôt think so? Ask yourself: How many Indigenous Montanans live in Missoula, a border town to the Salish & Kootenai Reservation? How many janitors live in the U District or Whitefish - places with schools that‚Ä¶I dunno‚Ä¶presumably need to be cleaned occasionally?

And since our local governments used their power to partly create the housing crisis - their classist, race-based policies choked growth for decades - they have the power and the responsibility to fix it.
Can‚Äôt believe this needs to be said, but it is in your community‚Äôs interest to *have places for the community to live*. üßµ

Our parties and our communities are better w/ truly competitive districts that force would-be public servants to earn their votes on a level playing field.

The League of Women Voters of MT are exactly right here and are using better data to determine competitiveness.

Unlike most of my fellow Democrats & Republicans - I flipped a competitive district.

Some people do not know what it means to try and earn meaningful support from people who do not have a D or R behind their name.

That is why they are afraid of competitive districts. #mtpol
This is the time for compromise - just please don‚Äôt compromise our values and the essential coalition members of our Party

I know that some of these maps were drawn in good faith with an eye towards competitiveness first and foremost - which is great!

But we have to be leaders here. We have to make our case to Montanans that we aren‚Äôt corrupt & awful like MT Republicans.

Democrats gerrymandering around Bozeman & Missoula + leaving Native, rural, & low-income Montanans in the lurch - is frankly immoral.

Montana Democrats used to lead this state - the *whole* state. We cannot turn tail & hide in the cities when our citizens need us most. #mtpol

We can have a competitive district and one that is truly representative of all our people.

Montanans expect it. Let‚Äôs do the right thing and come together on a map that makes our next Representative work for us - not their Party or special interests.

I know my honesty here will draw the ire of many Democratic Party insiders.

But what‚Äôs the point of being involved in this democratic project if we are only in it to push partisan talking points?

We cannot do a gerrymander - and we cannot abandon Native representation.

Montana Democrats have something special. For more than a century we‚Äôve provided the example of strong progressive community-focused leadership to the state and the country.

We owe it to those MT Democrats who fought for generations to get us what we currently have.

We cannot allow ourselves to do what certain corporate friendly Democrats in Washington DC  have done: abandon vast swaths of voters for the relative safety of the rich and connected cities.

More than anything - we must be honest. The People are watching.

MT has sent Dems to the Senate for more than 100 years.

MT Dems gave the country the Wilderness Act, MT Dems worked with Labor to break the back of monopolies, and that legacy continues to protect MT workers, voting rights, and some of our nation‚Äôs most treasured landscapes.
Montana Democrats have something special. For more than a century we‚Äôve provided the example of strong progressive community-focused leadership to the state and the country.
Either way - retreating to the safety of wealth and/or privileged urban whiteness will permanently relegate the Democratic Party to minority status in Montana.
The maps proposed by the Democratic Party infrastructure perfectly overlay where the richest donors live.

Where do you think most of the big money donors that support the Democratic Party infrastructure live?

It‚Äôs not Evergreen.

Our Party is at a crossroads not just in Montana but nationwide.

Either the Party is too afraid to represent working people, rural people, communities of color - or we‚Äôre experiencing donor capture.

We must have confidence in our message we can bring to towns like Columbia Falls, Heart Butte, Libby, Ennis, and Darby.

What does it say if we carve them out of Western Montana just because we don‚Äôt think they‚Äôll ever vote for us?

I get that a lot of Democratic candidates here want a Party that orients itself around the wealthy part-time residents and donors of Bozeman & Missoula.

But where does that leave the rest of us? Without a Party that cares for the struggle of working Montanans.

The numbers back me up.

Presidential results are not germain in this case. We must look at recent congressional performances.

But, Tom, don‚Äôt we have to gerrymander to get a competitive district?

No. We‚Äôre using the wrong numbers to determine competitiveness & working backwards from a defeatist mentality.

Trust me. I‚Äôm a progressive that won a race in a state house district that Trump carried by 11%.

If you‚Äôre unmoved by equal representation please consider what this means for Jon Tester. He relies on the high margins & high turnout of the Native vote to win.

With no statewide race in 2022 we will see depressed resources for getting out the native vote in a safe R district.

If we pass a map that puts 75% of Native American voters and all but 1 tribal nation into a 65+% GOP district we will cause irreparable harm to native Democratic activism. 

The commission must bridge these divides.
To say nothing of ensuring not only a Jon Tester loss in 2024. But also the abandonment of Montana‚Äôs native community by Montana Democrats.
The long term health of the Party rests in a broad coalition of Montanans, not just the elite donor classes in deeply unequal towns like Bozeman and Missoula.

I am saying this because I care. About Montana. About progressive politics. About the Democratic Party.

We cannot be allowed to balkanize ourselves into rich white enclaves.

The redistricting maps MT Dems have drawn do not prioritize native representation & working class voters & many do not pass the eye test for a gerrymander.
